entry.et: Middle English succeden, from Anglo-French succeeder, from Latin succedere to go up, follow after, succeed, from sub- near + cedere to go sub-

def.dt: :to come next after another in office or position or in possession of an estate
:to attain a desired object or end students who succeed in college
:to pass to a person by inheritance
:to follow in sequence and especially immediately
:to come after as heir or successor
